team the stream aligned team can also be called the product team this is the team

now the way that I know about cognitive load theory is because I'm teaching teachers how to teach computer science
at the University actually at the moment I'm teaching the next teacher how to
teach computer science at the University so it's very meta
and the way that I think about cognitive load is when I'm teaching and when I'm teaching these teachers
it's about how many things should you should you actually put into a presentation how many things should you
put into an assignment how many different concepts should you talk about when you have a session with somebody
who needs to learn something the cognitive load theory was created in 1982 by John sweller
and the simple way of looking at it is like this graph so we have the cognitive load how much
you're saying on the horizontal axis and you have the learning outcome on the vertical axis
and it's no big surprise that the more you s the more you say the more you teach the higher the learning outcome
becomes but the interesting thing which might be counter-intuitive and definitely is for
a lot of University lecturers if you've ever been to one is that at one point you have a sweet spot
and if you continue to talk about new things if you continue to introduce new Concepts after the students have hit
this sweet spot the learning is actually deteriorating it's not just stagnating but you're
ruining what you already told them because the brain is so cognitive loaded the brain is busy trying to take the
things from the working memory and put them into the long-term memory as patterns and schemas
but if you continue to talk they will learn less than if you shut up
but that's not something that teachers like to hear so James Weller made this fancy Theory
so that they could learn about it let's go into details about this
so the cognitive load actually consists of three different things
the first one is the intrinsic cognitive load the intrinsic cognitive load is the
smallest amount of information that you need in order to explain a subject the smallest amount of information that you
need in order to make meaning of A New Concept you cannot reduce it without reducing understanding
the next part of the cognitive load is extraneous cognitive load and extraneous
cognitive load is a non-intrinsic cognitive load that interferes with
rather than contributes to learning so this is extra information that you tell people that are actually confusing them
more than it's helping them the last part is the Germain cognitive load and the domain cognitive load is
non-attractive cognitive load that contributes to the learning rather than interferes with the learning
and you can think about this as maybe if you're if you're explaining
something like with patterns or with schemas you're helping people trying to
understand and trying to remember these things so what you want to do is that when you
want to figure out how much cognitive load you have in the presentation you add everything up
and some of it it all fills into the cognitive load but some of it is helping and some of it is hindering so what you
want to do to optimize the learning is to minimize the extraneous load and maximize the Germain load but if you're
looking at this slide then what part of this is the extraneous
cognitive load any ideas what's on this slide that's making you more confused

to some people the graph is sort of the intrinsic cognitive load this is the
